story.storykicker: With the latest OS update, the K4 Note users will be able to use features like Google Now on Tap, Doze, and revamped app permission.
story.storybody:
Lenovo has started rolling out the Android 6.0 Marshmallow to its K4 Note smartphone. The phones will get the Android update in a phased manner starting today.

With the latest OS update, the K4 Note users will be able to use features like Google Now on Tap, Doze, and revamped app permission. The update will most likely be layered upon Lenovo's own VibeUI.

The K4 Note, which is the successor to the K3 Note, was launched in January this year at Rs 11,999.

The phone comes with a 64-bit octa-core MediaTek processor, which is backed by 3GB RAM and 16GB of internal memory. The phone also comes with a fingerprint sensor. The Lenovo K4 Note was launched with Android 5.1 Lollipop, topped with the company's VibeUI.

The phablet carries a 5.5-inch FullHD IPS display layered with Corning Gorilla Glass 3 protective covering. The K4 Note phone is also the first phone to come with Dolby Atmos speakers. It has a pair of front speakers which support Dolby Atmos sound technology.

Also read: Lenovo K4 Note: Top features, specifications, price and everything you need to know

Lenovo claims that it has sold over 600,000 units of the K4 Note, along with 150,000 units of ANT VR headset, which was bundled with the phone for Rs 12,499. The VR headset can also be bought separately for Rs 1,299.

The company earlier rolled out the Marshmallow update to K3 Note, A7000, Vibe P1, Vibe S1 and Vibe X3 smartphones. The K4 Note is the sixth phone from the company to have received the Android 6.0 update.

The Android Marshmallow update comes a little too late for all those who are already looking forward to the Android N. Recent reports showed that a little over 7 per cent Android users have received the Marshmallow update so far. About 25 per cent of all users are still using versions from 2012 or earlier.

Google had launched Android N developer preview for Nexus phones in March this year. The Alphabet company may launch the yet-to-be-named Android later this year. However, the developer preview has been receiving updates and features suggesting a complete UI overhaul for the upcoming Android.

Also read: Why your Android phone may never get latest features
